update.description:
Allows to spawn multiple models by specifying its region, distribution and number of objects.

It requires [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/112) sdformat pull request.

**Known limitations:**

* The objects can collide each other when using a random distribution. 
* There are different alternatives for specifying the position of the models, but nothing is ready to specify orientations.

**Open question:** The Population class needs a pointer to the world and access to the private `rootElement` class member. This is required for spawning the models without using the transport. I included Population as a friend class inside the World class but I'm open for suggestions (create a public accessor to `rootElement`, use the transport for spawning models).

**Update**: Solved using `InsertModelString()`

**Update**: A new tutorial has been created [here](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/32/new-tutorial-for-model-population).

![gazebo_population.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/98514253-gazebo_population.png)
update.title: Automatic model population

content.raw: I thought we were using "include-what-you-need". This is used in World.cc but I can remove them.
content.html: I thought we were using "include-what-you-need". This is used in World.cc but I can remove them.

content.raw: A final postcondition (assert) for checking that _poses is not null?
content.html: A final postcondition (assert) for checking that _poses is not null?

content.raw: Maybe we can check that _modelCount is not negative or even zero.
content.html: Maybe we can check that _modelCount is not negative or even zero.

content.raw: s/fabs/std::abs
content.html: s/fabs/std::abs

content.raw: We could use an assertion as a postcondition for ```_poses.size() =1``` ?
content.html: We could use an assertion as a postcondition for _poses.size() =1 ?

content.raw: too many method parameters, we could consider to add them to a struct or a class.
content.html: too many method parameters, we could consider to add them to a struct or a class.

content.raw: We are using the same "Populate" word for these set of functions that really don't do the same than ```PopulateAll`` or ```PopulateOne```. Just semantics.
content.html: We are using the same "Populate" word for these set of functions that really don't do the same than PopulateAll`` orPopulateOne```. Just semantics.

content.raw: Since this is a private method and poses and output variable we can add a check to verify that _poses was empty. Otherwise we could be passing the wrong variables or in a wrong state.
content.html: Since this is a private method and poses and output variable we can add a check to verify that _poses was empty. Otherwise we could be passing the wrong variables or in a wrong state.

content.raw: I remember that fabs is not portable on Windows, so we could try using std::abs. Check this [pull request](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-request/8/portability-fixes-from-visual-c-2013/diff)
content.html: I remember that fabs is not portable on Windows, so we could try using std::abs. Check this pull request

content.raw: We could add a QA check counting the number of models in world previous to the for and check if the number after the for structure is the old number + objects.size(), or I am missing something else ...
content.html: We could add a QA check counting the number of models in world previous to the for and check if the number after the for structure is the old number + objects.size(), or I am missing something else ...

content.raw: Private method, a non NULL _population could be checked at this point.
content.html: Private method, a non NULL _population could be checked at this point.

content.raw: is a ```return false``` missing here?
content.html: is a return false missing here?

content.raw:
We are repeating this pattern of: 

* Check for the element
* Error and return false if not found
* Store the element if found

Sounds to me like we could try to unified a function for this at some point.
content.html:
We are repeating this pattern of:

  • Check for the element
  • Error and return false if not found
  • Store the element if found

Sounds to me like we could try to unified a function for this at some point.

content.raw: Since it is a private method, we could include a```GZ_ASSERT(_population)```
content.html: Since it is a private method, we could include aGZ_ASSERT(_population)

content.raw: As a pre-requisite for this method, we could include a ```GZ_ASSERT(this->populationElem)```
content.html: As a pre-requisite for this method, we could include a GZ_ASSERT(this->populationElem)

It's a little bit cleaner to do:

if (_sdf->HasElement("population"))
  this->populationElem = _sdf->GetElement("population");

content.raw: See pull request #1167
content.html: See pull request #1167

content.raw: done, ticketed issue #1258
content.html: done, ticketed issue #1258

content.raw: This include should be removed
content.html: This include should be removed

content.raw: This set of includes should be removed.
content.html: This set of includes should be removed.

content.raw: Could you use a private data class here?
content.html: Could you use a private data class here?

content.raw: Would you mind filing an issue for that? You can assign to me or @\_jrivero_
content.html: Would you mind filing an issue for that? You can assign to me or @_jrivero_

content.raw:
Reordered header file in `test/integration/world_population.cc` in d6115b9  to allow it to run with all physics engines (was previously running with ode only). 

Probably need to ticket an issue about the fact that certain ordering of the header files disables running tests with different params
content.html:
Reordered header file in test/integration/world_population.cc in d6115b9 to allow it to run with all physics engines (was previously running with ode only).

Probably need to ticket an issue about the fact that certain ordering of the header files disables running tests with different params
